Could've got me kicked out if I didn't explain to the board what happened. Jerk.

Fletcher was by far the best prof I have had in University. To put into perspective, I went from 72% in ENVS178 to 89% in ENVS278. His lectures were well-structured. I'm not sure why people are hating on him!! He provided a summary of the textbook at the beginning of the term!? I'm not saying he is an easy prof, but you have to put the effort in!

Hands down best prof at Waterloo and has an excellent teaching method, he involved the class in his lectures, and gave many resources. I went from a 65% in ENVS 178 to a 92% in ENVS 278. If you do bad in his class it's because you: aren't reviewing enough, don't come to class enough, or if you do come to class you aren't paying attention.

Not sure why everyone's hating... I'm not even a math person but if you ask, he will explain. He's very caring and approachable. Most students' predicament with him is that he calls on you randomly in class for extra 2%, but it was the only way I kept myself from zoning out & to really try and pay attention. No penalty for getting the answer wrong.

He does a good job at teaching the material and concepts. Course doesn't focus a lot on maths skills, it's based on those statistical concept, and eventually gets boring. Prof is caring and tries his best to engage his students.
Did not learn much.
This prof is awful. Never want to take his course again!
I loved and enjoyed stat in my first year, and now he made me hate the stat.
things are unclear. also, heavy assignments . problem is that this lecture won't help you to do your assignment...
Doesn't explain things very clear. Randomly calls students' names to participate during the class, which i hate most.
Never take his class

Very dedicated to the class, tries to make it engaging. He is very helpful if you go see him in office hours and will go our of his way to make sure you understand concepts. The final assignment was challenging, but marked fairly easily. It provided a chance to practically apply concepts from the course in a real world context.

Asks questions on review quizzes on topics not discussed in class or in text book chapter. Does not explain things well, slides are useless if you want to review. Doesn't prove complete examples of the use of equations. This is a second year course. I'm in 4th year and it will probably be my lowest grade.

Very rude, lectures are practically useless for all online assignments and exams. Major paper (50%) is poorly laid out with very little direction. Prof refuses to communicate through email? Yeah... You have to go to office hours for every little problem. Terrible prof.
A very knowledgeable professor who really cared about the topic and his student. The MPs were complex at times but he was lenient and understanding of the student workload and time.
Class was hard in my opinion. The final exam was a killer, miles harder than any of the midterms.
Genius teaches Neanderthals how to make artificial intelligence. Tests are hard, but MPs are worth most of the points and are manageable. Great class, almost as important as DS&A.

The professor didn't explain himself very well. The concept is interesting but hard and the professor did very poor job helping us understand. And the mp homework was ridiculous. You will only learn how to use a couple of python libraries but won't have a better understanding of the concept

One of the best lecturer in ECE department. He explains thing extremely well. When he talk about some theorem, he would definitely give us intuition about it and his own process of understanding when he studied the same material.

Topic itself is interesting and professor gives good lectures. But midterms are EXTREMELY HARD and TOTALLY DIFFERENT from practice exams, and MPs take tons of time. If you still need sleep and don't wanna ruin your GPA, please avoid this course and professor.
He is a decent professor, and relative to the others that teach AI at UIUC he is amazing.

Not very good at explaining the material. It's as if he is just reading definitions out loud during class with out helping build any intuition. You should definitely try to get into the other lecture.
He makes everything very clear!!(but ece313 is an easy course anyway) But sometimes his lecture can get pretty boring.

The most well spoken Engineering professor there is. His notes were extremely clear, and he was good at helping people. Barely ever made mistakes when writing on the chalk board like most absent minded Engineering professors.

One of the best professors in ECE.  He gave great lectures, and assigned interesting projects.  He was a little too mathematical for my taste, but he explained the concepts very clearly. I understood everything even after sleeping through the derivations.  303 is a great class, highly recomended.
One of the best professors for computer vision!

She just reads slides out loud in class. She doesn't really care if you understand it. She isn't one of those teachers that tries to built up to concepts, or walk you through the intuition behind understanding something. Its more like here is information, I'm just going to keep pushing through slides. Her MPs are great however.
CS 444 is one of the worst classes I have taken at uiuc. Absolutely no structure to the class whatsoever, do not recommend.
One of the best professors that I have ever met!

Class covers some extremely interesting concepts. Svetlana does a piss poor job of explaining them in lecture. Her lecture slides consist of condensed material from a textbook and she literally reads the slides aloud in class. There are no explanations nor any followup discussions apart from the ones she prepares beforehand.
She is clear and consistent with her lectures. Materials are interesting.
Excellent preparation and time management. She is a very sincere professor and the best I've ever had.

Quite a poor professor. She has interesting research but has no clue how to properly lecture. Slides are verbatim from the book as are the exams. Does not help at office hours and has a terrible laugh. Keeps track of students attendance mentally… and calls you by name. Awkward.
Terrible professor. Boring lectures, unhelpful in office hours, exams are entirely memorization.
Very boring lectures, slides are a condensed version of relevant book chapters, graded class participation, exam is entirely memorization, unhelpful TAs

Great lectures. Gives good intuition. Lots of good advice. Lots of opinions. Lots of math- not a bad thing. Lots of notation and terminology. Really need to know linear algebra and probability/statistics! His research area is ML theory; since deep learning isn't well-understood, he looks at what's done in practice- knows a lot about implementation.
In most of his lectures, Prof. Telgarsky did nothing but read the slides. It didn't take long for me to stop attending his class and start to simply read the slides and textbooks by myself.

This professor is certainly really good at this area I could tell. He has solid math background, and can derive theories and proofs on lectures without referring to textbook and other materials. 
However, this course is definitely hard. Homework is hard, quizzes are hard. He is not good at teaching. There are four examinations along the semesters.
good class to take
The course is designed to contain lots of topics so it takes fair amount of time to study after each lecture. Solomonik is always well prepared for lectures and is very helpful during office hours.

I learned much about numerical analysis in this course. Also, the weekly homework are well-designed but time consuming . There is video recording for each lecture. However, the instructor's pace is too fast and his lecture notes is not stable (updated frequently). I guess few students could catch up with his lecture. It took me a lot of time on it

One of the best CS courses I've taken at UIUC so far. Super interesting content that is a great blend of math, computing, and sociology. Easy to succeed, while still teaching you a lot. Awesome professor who you will have many opportunities to meaningfully interact with. Engaging group discussions. Can't recommend enough! :)
The lecture is not even recorded. You need to self study a lot.

It is said that this would be a reversed class settings. I wonder if this was an excuse for prof being lazy and not giving lectures. Think about it, the promised lectures were just a 5min lecture before class, leaving no chance for me to understand what he was talking about. The whole course is depending on selfstudy, so why do we even need a prof?

Professor Sundaram is an easy-going professor. He is ALWAYS nice, considerate, and helpful to his students. The course content is well-designed. It's a very good 500-level course grad students, which is very inspirational.

6 quizzes but no exams means you will need to catch up the class all the time. I especially love the way he insisted on no cheatsheet policy, as he never tested on memorization, but only on understanding. After I graduate from UIUC, I found lots of stuff learned in CS412 turns out to be very useful and inspiring in the future study.
One of the worst lecturer I've had for a CS class. Keeps repeating himself and the flow when he explains is extremely unclear and difficult to follow. Avoid if possible.
He is very helpful, clear and knows what is he doing. I actually learned how to write a decent lab report from him. Highly recommended!
The only good  orgo lab professor at CSI. Highly respected professor.

This is the only course where I learnt and implemented important concepts for conducting research. It was not the easiest class but it was the most rewarding. I had to spend a LOT of time (~ 20 + hrs/week) learning and researching things I wasn't familiar with. I am glad I stuck through it. Prof. Farivar is always there to help clarify things.

This was the most challenging course I have taken thus far but I really did learn a lot. If you do not have the time to invest in this course DO NOT take it. There are weekly assignments to complete and although the criteria and instructions were not clear in the beginning, it got better. Prof. Farivar is helpful and really nice!

He was awful. The most disorganized professor I ever had. He uploads the the guide and rubric that you need in order to write your lab the night before the lab is due. He doesn't even know when the last day of class and plans something on a day that we don't even have right before final exams. He does teach you some useful stuff.
Amazing professor, amazing class. You will spend lots of time on this class, but so worth it. You learn so much!!! Loved him!

Prof. Farivar provided a syllabus in the beginning of the term that ended up being followed for about half of the marks. The rest were arbitrarily assigned. This prof did not help with work at all, but rather assigned it to his TA (who should've been teaching the class). Unbelievable workload.

Weekly assignments, will require a lot of work but is very worth it. Learned so much, would recommend this class to anyone. He expects a lot from students and helps you along the way. Most helpful and informative course I've taken at McGill by far. Avoid if you don't have the time to put into it.

Reza definitely knows the material, just struggles a bit with the delivery. A relatively new prof at McGill, he's still getting into the groove of teaching undergraduate students. (He's improving with each year, thankfully.) Tough exams but certainly possible to get an A. Advice: Get the NTCs for his lectures. They will save you. &Do the readings.
Lectures are absolute trash. This prof should resign, makes cool thing uninteresting.
Great lecturer! Unlike many profs, he cares about teaching and really tries to engage you and prompt your thoughts. The exams are very fair too.

I loved Prof Farivar. You really need to go to the lectures and make very good notes in order to do well in this class--all midterms and final are very lecture based. Lots of opportunities for extra credit and very interesting lectures and content, but fairly science based and requires a lot of work. Loved the class and prof, would recommend.

Type up word for word the lectures and go to class for the extra credit. Reading the textbook is pointless. It's a lot of work but trust me it's worth it since his exams are only lecture based. Also quite hard for students, like me, who are not in science or do not have some background.

I took this class and easily got an A-. If you know how to study and read all his slides a few times, (which aren't many), than you will get an A. Make sure to look at the picture diagrams and understand what is going on because they will be tested. Anyone who says this class is hard is just a first year who came from a poor public education.

If you put the effort into this class, then it is certainly possible to do well. There were 3 (!) midterms, which while annoying, did help to boost grades. Lectures were long and confusing, mostly because the prof never wrote down explanations of important concepts, he just spoke, so I had to and I had to rewatch part of the lecture every week .

Take PSYC 311 BEFORE PSYC 212. Michalakis Petrides explains a lot of the same topics covered in this class except in a much more interesting and cohesive manner. Avoid this class at all costs. I would recommend this course to anyone who needs to drop their GPA as fast as possible.  6
worst class ever

His lectures were straight forward and he made it clear what material would be tested. The material was slightly difficult but this was mostly offset my his teaching style and the help of lecture recordings.

Even though the class itself is one of the toughest class I've taken in McGill, Reza is not a bad guy. He gets a bad rep because of the class itself. The clicker questions are EXTREMELY similar to his midterm and final questions. He really does care for his students. ATTEND CLASS!

My favourite Prof I've had at McGill thus far!! The course material is very interesting and Prof Reza's passion easily rubs off on you. Testing is tough, but if you listen carefully, he reallly does tell you everything you need to know, no textbook required. Course is super easy with a science background, harder with arts. And free 7% bonus!

I respect everyone's perspective about this class but I do however believe a majority of these negative comments were due to final exam pressure. Material isn't very difficult, is very interesting and I think Reza is an AMAZING PROFESSOR. I promise the others are just exaggerating. Re-listen to lectures as you go and all is good. Exams tough

Prof really cares for us and wants us to learn. His exams are hard but it's not out of bad faith. Though he's learning every year and tries to make it better. He gave up 7% bonus and curves the exams. People are being too unfair because of the difficulty of the exams. It's very doable.

Very little emphasis on what concepts actually matter and little to no clarity when describing things. Often happens that the Professor mixes up his words and speaks in long, non-concise riddles that simply frustrated me throughout the whole course, making it very difficult to learn, let alone enjoy a class i was excited for.

this prof is absolutely horrible. He treated a 200-level course as a 400-level. Exams are beyond difficult. He doesn't seem to care about his students. Makes very snide comments. Lectures are extremely boring. He will post a picture and mumble for 15min and then test you on it. He sucks at explaining. If you don't need this class, DO NOT TAKE IT!

He is Terrible, do not take this course. He can be rude and materials are extremely hard,  he thinks we have background in science. His evaluation methods are terrible and does not care if he students pass or fail.

His lectures are extremely hard to follow as he tends to go back and forth, mumbles, assumes we understand things we obviously don't, etc. His exams are the most difficult/ambiguous/impossible exams I have ever encountered at McGill. He really needs to change his teaching/testing methods because they are obviously not working.
This professor is terrible. Unclear and boring.

He tends to mumble and talk fast through important information, and since he makes the exams entirely lecture-based it can be an issue. I would suggest getting the book and reading through at least most of the topics covered in class, because his explanations can be cluttered and incoherent. Also two weeks between midterms is kind of pointless.

Horrible. Unclear, inconsistent, disorganized. He does not grade in time, has too many midterms with only 2 WEEKS distance in between, does not provide feedback about your exams, is unfair in grading criteria, and his short answer questions (and MC) are the most ambiguous questions ever. Can be funny, but doesn't make up for his poor teaching.

He speaks so fast that it is almost impossible to take proper notes in class. His short answer questions for exams require unnecessary drawings that cause students to lose so many points. Too bad it's a mandatory class for many and too bad he's the professor. There are so many other profs better suited for this position. He can be rude too.

Reza is actually an amazing professor! He's so passionate about what he teaches and he makes the subject really interesting and definitely livens up lectures. He genuinely cares about perception! Tests are definitely tough (study extremely well) but the content and the prof make it so worthwhile. Would definitely take again!! 10/10 would recommend.

Class was very difficult especially if you do not have a background in the sciences.  Professor Farivar is a nice guy but lectures as if we know everything already. Would not recommend taking his class if you are not in the sciences.

Professor Farivar lectures as though he expects his students to already have some background knowledge on each topic ... His tests are super tough (multiple choice + short answers) and often require you to draw diagrams. He talks super fast in class and you need a clicker! Would NOT recommend - HARD

Dr. Farivar is a great prof! He is very down-to-earth and interesting. He may not make you simply read the book and test you on it later, but his classes are enjoyable, impose a fair challenge and make you LEARN instead of memorizing what he teaches. Hopefully he gets to teach other classes too, he's really great.

People, often get upset by his lecture style as it is based around figures and clicker questions. His slides have very little info so you have to ask questions and really listen to get an idea of whats going on. Read the text or google if you are lost on a concept. Really nice guy though who is trying hard to shake things up.

Reza's not a bad professor--its a hard class! I The textbook content and lecture material is just very dense, and the questions are more applied knowledge rather than memorization. An A is feasible if you do the readings, however I recommend doing them BEFORE class, and then redoing them after but just refocusing on what he talks about in lecture.

Worst class I have ever taken in my life. If you're not in science and have no background in it STAAAYYYYY AWAAAYYYYY. It's the worst. So much reading about stuff you don't understand. The way he teaches and tests is horrible. Let him gain experience first.

DO NOT TAKE. By far the worst psyc class i've taken at McGill. He'll make you use your clicker to answer questions. Sometimes he would barely explain the answer. Mid term and final are both hard. But you get an extra 10% if you write 2 papers and answer the clicker questions. If this class isn't required for you, then just don't.

I really don't get where these ratings are coming from, I personally found Dr. Farivar's midterm and exam challenging but fair. You will definitely need to take good notes from the textbook and pay attention to the questions he asks in class. The question style is the same in the exams. I read the chapter before attending class and managed an A.

There's no doubt that his test are tough and I admit it, but I managed to pass this course with a B, and I'm not in science! This course is not easy, so take it only if you have to!  He is not a bad lecturer but rather the material is so dense and not very interesting. Textbook is very boring but his classes are fun. weird test questions btw!

It is definitely not an easy class. It was the teacher's first time teaching and you could definitely tell. The lectures are dry and very hard to comprehend if you haven't read the corresponding chapter before the class. There are 2 tests both 50% each and extremely difficult. He does give the chance for 10% bonus which is needed, due to hard exams

Midterm & final 50% each, and opportunity for up to 10% bonus. First time teaching, wasn't the best. In his defense, the textbook is awful. He learned from the midterm that it was too difficult, and final was made easier. Lectures can be dry, but tries to engage class with clicker questions. Wouldn't advise to take as an elective. An A is feasible.

This is by far the worst course I have taken at McGill so far, and this prof is entirely the reason for it. The lectures were boring and his teaching amounted to nothing more than dry textbook regurgitation. Grading is harsh, questions harder than need be, and there are only two exams. I feel like I've wasted both my time and money. Stay away!

His lectures are comprehension-based, but it's not a bad thing since they help you to grasp the main points of the chapters. The vast majority of his questions are based on the lectures, so it's possible to do decently even when u skip all the details not mentioned in class. I was never into science but found myself enjoying it more than I expected

It is his first time teaching and it shows. The 1st half of the semester + the midterm was disastrous, honestly the hardest test I have ever taken and I studied A LOT. He adjusted his teaching after the midterm, and I understood a lot more after that. His teaching style is just not the most fitting for this 200-level class. Tests are very tricky.
He did not teach at all, all we did were clicker questions, exams were unbearably hard and vague. Nearly all the exam questions are tricky.  If you can AVOID AT ALL COST.

His lectures are based on comprehension, not memorization. It may sound cool, but the course structure is a DISASTER. He does not teach anything about the textbook, his midterm is unfairly tricky and vague, midterm and final (which is cumulative) are equally weighted, you have to write 6 pages to earn 2.5% bonus. Avoid at all costs. :

It's his first time teaching and it showed... His midterm was so confusing and vague, and on top of that there were plenty of mistakes in it.  Repeated material in class word for word from textbook and didn't give additional explanation. Won't attribute more weight to final if you do better on it than the midterm (50%50%).

Midterm was extremely unfair and horribly confusing (if  2 answers were right, had to bubble in each answer). It was also extremely long and super confusing since he doesn't teach us anything, just presents clicker qs and then moves on. Worst prof I have ever had at McGill - doesn't give us any guidelines of what to expect. TAs have to do his job.

Textbook's pretty bad, took him ages to upload a syllabus, poor TAs are covering for everything it seems, and doesn't teach, just gives questions based on the material you were meant to teach yourself from the textbook. Maybe if the textbook were better or he spoke a little slower the class would be interestingbetter, but I'm pretty disappointed.
This was a horrible class, DO NOT TAKE IT... especially as an elective. Thoroughly regret my decision

This guy is a massive dingus when it comes to exams.  This class is way too difficult and the textbook sucks.  There is 5% extra credit for clicker participation, which is  only thing his lectures consist of.  The other extra credit is almost too difficult to achieve and requires writing 10 pages on articles that are incomprehensible.

I can say he's one of the best profs I've ever had at McGill. Very clear, absolutely cares about his students. The course material is hard and kinda dry, but his lectures are very interesting. He doesn't complicate stuff. Im not a science person at all, but the way he teaches made it easy for me to understand the material in this course.

Worst professor I've had. I agree with everyone here, he doesn't teach. Everything is based on his clickers and if you want a 2.5% increase you have to write a six page essay. His exams are super hard (you have to circle two answers on some questions, if one is wrong, you don't get a point). Failed the class big time. DO NOT TAKE HIM.
This class made me think about science completely different than I did before. Very inspiring!

who designs a multiple choice exam where you need to circle more than one answer to receive the point!? a ridiculous 6 page paper to receive only 2.5% extra credit?! I almost feel like he wants the class to fail. & you basically have to teach yourself with the dense, confusing textbook because he doesn't really teach. hopefully he picks up his game

I can't believe this is a 200 level course AND listed as an elective for arts students. I'm majoring in psychology and I have never struggled so hard in a class. The readings are dense, long and unnecessarily complicated. As everybody else said, the prof doesn't teach whatsoever, only asks clicker questions. I'd never show up if it wasn't worth 5%.

I think his clicker questions are engaging, and a few do come up on the midterm. He expects us to have read the chapters before coming to class, which is fair. He tends to slur over words quickly, which sometimes make it hard to understand, esp when the concept is complex. As his midterm was quite difficult, I'm glad that he gives us extra credits.

The professor has a lot of potential, unfortunately it's his first year and he's still figuring it out.  He bases his lectures on concepts rather than facts, which can seem difficult but helpful.  The textbook is crap, the author was fired on tenor and the assistant authors also admitted it was crap.  Takes hours to understand a chapter.

He is not clear at all, he doesn't teach new material; his lecture are just MC questions to answer with a clicker and his exams are tough and unfair. You can study the textbook and his questions for days and still struggle because questions are ambiguous and don't test really what you have been studying. Upside is there's a lot of extra credit

he frustrates me. His midterm was worth 50% and it was so unclear. The class would be better if he actually taught us stuff rather than just asking clicker questions (and then not explaining the answer). such a disconnect between difficulty of lecturestextbook and exam questions. beware: if you can avoid, please do.

Hands down the WORST prof I've ever had. He refuses to teach - the lectures are based on very tricky clicker questions, which means he expects you to come to class having already mastered the material. The midterm was ridiculously hard, its like he actually wanted us to do bad on it. Just memorize the textbook and hope it will be enough to pass.

Worst prof i have ever had at McGill. Presents material in a very confusing and subjective way. Lectures consists of him asking clicker questions and you get a 5% bonus for participation, but he doesn't teach anything. Basically have to teach yourself the class by reading the textbook and figuring out what he might test on. Midterm was confusing.

he said this class "wouldn't be like a normal class" - that he wouldn't just passively regurgitate the textbook. what i didn't realize was that he meant he wouldn't be teaching. lectures consist purely of clicker questions. if the class answers incorrectly, he just repeats the question rather than providing any guidance or, well, teaching.

He does not teach! All he does is ask clicker questions and insist on application. When it came time for the midterm, it was very difficult. His course structure is not balanced (50% midterm, 50% final , 5% bonus for TWO FIVE PAGE papers, 5% bonus for participation). Very arrogant. Sometimes wasn't worth going to class which would only go 30 mins
Engaging and interesting class.
Class itself is really hard and a bit disorganized but Wang is a great lecturer and really explains the concepts well
Lectures are sleepy and way too easy.
Amazing professor! Very easy class, so you don't have to fret about the work. She very caring and will help you as much as she can. If she's not able to, she'll ask someone. TAKE HER!!!

Professor Cunningham is an administrator for the CTLE.  She is a great teacher!  I don't like the BA101 class because it could be done in less time--but she is a great person and a great teacher!  I would highly recommend over any other BA101 teacher.

Prof. Zhang is amazing as a lecturer. He gets students to participate in class, and even asks his students questions during lecture, which I like. Unfortunately, it takes a while for assignments and tests to be graded, and he can be confusing when communicating information to students. I also felt a little uncomfortable asking him questions.

This course is a serious upper-level class and he expects you to be as proficient as his graduate students, but he is a very generous grader and gives pretty easy exams. He expects you to not need much direction on the course project but, again, it's a senior level class so you need to be prepared to work hard. Also is doing crazy cool research.

Such a nice teacher! Like his slides, clear and straight to the point. Only three home works and one group project, two exams that are so easy if you simply review his slides. Everything I learned in this course is proved to be useful. This is the best course I ever took.
This course really useful. Professor chooses some real good topics which is useful in the industry. Learnt quite a lot during the course.
Tests were well outlined, with a well defined review given for the test. The project was difficult, but extra credit was given and I feel that I learned a lot from it.

Really good professor that gives a clear outlined lecture. Tests are fair and feel like I learned a fair bit of practical knowledge from his class. Project is extremely hard though, don't take if you don't want to do any coding.

The class was pretty good. It's an easy class so if you just follow his instructions and his slides you will be ok. Tests are fairly easy. It was a low stress class form me. He's a good guy just takes some patience to get used to. If you are a student at UTD you probably know that half the professors have accents anyway. No big deal to me.

Stopped attending class when his lectures confused me even more than trying to read the poorly written slides. Which is surprising considering he mostly reads the slides. When the majority of the class failed the first test with a review provided, his response was to not even provide a review for the second test. Only positive is he curves at end.
Amazing professor. Knows the material inside out and makes classes very enjoyable.
Very active outside the class communications. Prompt in answering any doubts.

The lectures are very good, but their relevance to the actual assignments and quizzes is lacking. You are pretty much on your own for assignments, because it seems like they dont have answers themselves.

Good lectures with some humor scattered about. This was an online course so I was surprised by his quick responses in the student forums. His explanations are clear and helpful. His course includes a particularly challenging routing assignment that provides good opportunities to learn.
super cool teacher, recommend his CS538 and CS241
clear lecture! nice person
Very clear on his lecture, coolest professor I've met.
interesting guy
Chillest Prof you can ever have. Amazing Guy.

Solid professor, though you need to try hard in the class.  Worth it to find a group of people you consistently meet with for homework.  Lab attendance is not mandatory but strongly recommended.  Not nearly as bad as people have said.  

Shoutout to Rhea Jain for the awesome labs.
Probably the worst CS teacher I've ever had. Lectures are useless, just do your best with the discussions and office hours.

Professor is very rude and arrogant. Does not care about student's personal Circumstances and is not empathetic to mental health at all or even otherwise. Has a very thick accent and does not know how to explain material. If you take this class prepare to teach yourself and beg for grades because there is no way this professor can teach you.

If you're not mathematically mature, DO NOT take his class. However, if you're up for a challenge then 100% take his class. He will push you to your absolute max and then some. This can be overwhelming for a lot, but stick through and you'll be surprised how much you improved in a semester. Also, deadly exams and HWs so don't overload.
Sloppy and doesnt go through material in lecture. Mostly says read the book. Tests dont match up with what we learn. HW is pretty hard

After answering every question with "check the syllabus" throughout the semester, a homework assignment was silently added to said syllabus with 4 weeks left of the semester. When I initially presented testing accommodations, I was told to take the exam with the rest of the class, or drop the course (way past the drop deadline, might I add).

He's a solid professor in terms of being able to teach. His prerecorded lectures were fantastic (with some humor here and there) and I learned an incredible deal from watching his lectures. However, his midterm exams were extremely difficult, and he didn't really provide much support to struggling students, which I hope he can improve on...
His true colors were revealed after I took his course online. Shows absolutely no care for teaching. Extremely unfair conditions especially given COVID times.
He's really rude to students and doesn't really care about students. His lecture was good, but he always gives really hard exams. Won't recommend taking courses with him.

He answers most questions with 'Please check the course website for rules' on piazza while the question is not answered in the rules at all, and he follows his every answer by '...' which is really discouraging to see when you're taking a hard course and the prof be like: you don't even know this??? Sometimes he even answers questions with 'Ha?'
Terrible Professor. Rude to students.
He despises his students. Condescending and patronizing. I will never take his course again.

Very worthwhile assignments. I think he tries to make things look easy but people just find it hard to get on his wavelength sometimes. When you go back and read what he says it makes a lot more sense, and his slides are great. Needs to work on communication, but written material is excellent.
His lectures aren't great, but his exams are pretty reasonable.

The first few lectures weren't great, but got better as the semester went on. Grading was fair; prof was helpful in office hours (if necessarily inaccessible outside office hours due to 500 person class size). Buy a textbook! (Recommended: Algorithm Design, Kleinberg-Tardos). Struggle through the assignments solo to learn the material better.
Issues mentioned are generally overblown. Knows how to build grit.

The course is difficult, that much is undeniable. Sariel has his weaknesses but at the end of the day he is incredibly intelligent and really provides students with the resources they need to succeed. I have much respect for him and am happy to have taken this course with his lead!
He gave horrible and tedious lectures. He was so mean to students and did not care if we got it or not. He even refused to answer questions about 374 during his office hour. Don't take his courses.

Avoid at all cost! 1)Literally the worst lecturer. Really thick accent and goes through concepts really fast without explaining in details. 2) Homework problems are really difficult to understand. Grammar errors and weird phrasings makes most students spend hours on piazza just asking for clarifications..

He's definitely not a good lecturer. I don't know how the CS department allowed him to teach a heavy course like CS374. On the other hand, I believe he's a great guy and genius. But lecturing is definitely not a thing for him.
Awful professor. Often responds to questions with 'use your common sense'. He is impossible to understand or hear, and is generally unhelpful or unreceptive to feedback.
Most horrible class ever

Seems to be a pretty smart guy, however his lectures are horribly difficult to hear much less comprehend, and since it's one of the hardest classes in the CS department, his horrible lecturing only makes it more unbearable.

Not a good instructor.An ultra smart guy and a brilliant researcher  yes, but not a good teacher! He assumes that you know everything, and doesn't get any feedback from the class.Doesn't answer questions.His bad accent exacerbates the problem.  His homeworks are crazy hard & doesn't grade them soon enough nor gives solutions.The exams are as hard.

Har-Peled is very smart but he just doesn't speak English well enough to get his point accross.    He would also tend to delve into lengthy proofs before explaining what the problem was or why it matters.   I doubt he has ever taken and Education course in his life.   He may be a brilliant researcher but he hasn't become a good teacher (yet).
Overall the course was taught very well. The professor knows his content and does a good job of communicating with the students.
Excellent professor. He knows the subject matter extremely well, very friendly, explains everything well. And goes easy on gradings as well :-)

He was a very average professor.  He seemed like a relatively friendly and approachable guy, but he didn't leave much of an impression on me.  He does a decent job of explaining the content, and 241 with him was moderately hard.

Excellent lecturer, the discussions that happen during her presentations are invaluable to learning pretty much anything in this course. So while attendance isn't mandatory, you're missing out on a huge portion of the class by skipping lecture. Only complaint is that is that the 1 midterm and 1 final can get you if you're not super prepared.

CS433 was a well instructed course taught by a passionate professor who truly cared about her students. Multiple times she would regularly ask us how the class was going (i.e. pacing, difficulty). The material was challenging (it's a 400 level course at UoI after all), but the ample resources and generous deadlines were enough to succeed.

Shocked to see the previous post. CS433 with Professor Adve is one of the most useful and inspiring courses I've taken in the CS department. The materials covered in this course are definitely hard, but the professor and the TA tried their best to make our lives easier. Been to both their office hours, I really appreciated their patience and help.

Excellent lectures. Really well versed in the material she teachers. Encourages lots of questions and exploring outside the basic curriculum. Hard tests with low averages, but thats alright when you're learning a lot!
Knows a lot about this stuff and makes an effort to make the class useful and interesting for everyone instead of strictly following book/slides

Terrible lecturer where the only reason most people went was to get iclicker points.  I watched all the lectures from the previous year online that had Craig Zilles teaching it.  She was very confusing and often wasted class time on useless things like trying to get students to ask questions when we had none and trying to learn 200 student's names.
Sarita is a great person. She is very excited about her research and teaching.
Very engaging professor, very knowledgeable, class is very discussion based, encourages questions tailors discussions based on how class is responding. Great professor.

Excellent professor. She really cared about her students learning, and we had some excellent discussions in class resulting from student questions. It's not a hard class either - one midterm and a non-cumulative final and around seven homeworks. Would definitely recommend to anyone interested in architecture.
Her class is very discussion-driven. She will stop and answer if you have any questions. The material is not fixed for each class, so you can expect to learn everything crystal clearly.

She made sure you understood material.  I personally think it's a very boring subject, so it's terribly difficult to stay focused.  Only 4 written hws (25%) and 2 exams (1 midterm (37%) and 1 final (38%)).  Thus, if you make a stupid mistake on one of the exams, you are screwed.
Content was very solid.  Responsive to class feedback.  Exceeded my expectations. Good class.
Scatter-brained
She sucks!  Got an A though.
Not the most exciting.  But she cares about her students and will put forth her full effort to help you learn which is more than I can say about a lot of other profs.
Lectures are very boring.  Prof tries to keep people awake by forcing participation, which is awkward and causes more people to ditch.  Homework and tests are OK.
Sarita Adve is HOT!  Take the class just for that reason alone!
No Comments
